item.description:
Tyrannosaur

Tyrannosaur by Paddy Considine (UK, 2011, 91 min.). A 2011 Sundance Film Festival award winner,Tyrannosaur tells the story of Joseph (Peter Mullan), an unemployed widower who has a drinking problem and a bad temper. He meets Hannah (Olivia Colman), who soon tempers his fury and offers him warmth, kindness, and acceptance. As their relationship develops, Hannah reveals that her husband (Eddie Marsan) is violent and abusive, and Joseph emerges as her unlikely savior.

With striking performances and a deeply felt story, actor-turned-writer/director Paddy Considine's film is a stunning debut about the emergence of grace and redemption from the least likely of places.

Violence Warning:  This film is unlikely to be a relaxing, pastoral experience.

Opening scenes don’t get much more challenging than Tyrannosaur’s, in which Peter Mullan’s protagonist, gripped by rage at some unseen insult, fatally kicks his dog. The act is no less disturbing for mostly taking place offscreen, and the unthinking brutality on Mullan’s face is as upsetting as any image the film could show anyway. Though Mullan looks and behaves like a monster, Tyrannosaur, the feature directorial debut of actor Paddy Considine, then asks viewers to care about him as he slowly tries to reclaim the humanity that he may no longer remember trading away.

"Tyrannosaur" is a film buoyed by exquisite performances and a keen understanding from its first-time director of the power of the absence of dialog."

"Considine’s almost unyielding gloom makes Tyrannosaur a tough sit. It lacks the leavening humour of the best work of Ken Loach, Considine’s most obvious influence (Mullan starred in Loach’s My Name is Joe).

But you won’t find two finer performances in recent times than those by Mullan and Colman, who in a perfect world would each have received Oscar nominations.

Superb actors both, they search for humanity amidst the social ruins."

 

Whew.  After, we'll definitely find a spot to decompress, descuss, and decant.

 

See you at the movie,

John
item.how_to_find_us: John will gather the group in the theater at the close of credits, then stand in the hallway with an incredibly valuable original authentic Red Meetup sign, if he hasn't created his own 'International/Arthouse Film Group' sign, first.
item.name: Tyrannosaur
